dataset.title: Herbivore and Habitat changes associated with the Roan Antelope decline in the Northern Kruger National Park

keywordSet.keyword: Roan Antelope, habitat change, northern plains

intellectualRights.para: SANParks should be aknowledge for the data capture and use. Digital and non-digital data and metadata belonging to the Kruger National Park Scientific Services are provided on an "as-is" basis with no guarantee as to data quality. Neither the staff nor South African National Parks (SANParks) may be held liable for any loss of any sort resulting from use of data and/metadata provided by Scientific Services.

section.title: Vegetation Survey
section.para: As the EAS vegetation assessment and veld condition assessment surveys only measure the herbaceous vegetation at a very coarse level, I conducted a separate vegetation survey to answer specific questions. The two main objectives of this vegetation survey were: 1) to compare vegetation inside and outside an enclosure to determine the general condition of the herbaceous layer in the roan’s range, and 2) to determine the effects that the artificial waterholes have had on the composition and abundance in the herbaceous layer. The vegetation survey was conducted in January 1994.

section.title: Comparison of vegetation inside and outside the enclosure
section.para: The enclosure used for this survey is known as Nwashitsumbe and is situated in the northeast of the roan’s range (refer to Figure 2.1). It is a square, 256 ha. Enclosure and has been protected from large numbers of grazers since 1970, except for 20 roan between 1970 and 1978, and 40 Lichtenstein’s hartebeest between 1991 and the time of the study. The eastern fence of the enclosure runs through an alluvial grassland, while the remaining three sides of the enclosure run through non-alluvial grassland.

Specific attributes that were measured included: composition, abundance, cover and height of the herbaceous layer. Sampling sites were located on both the outside and the inside of the four fence lines of the enclosure. Sampling sites were positioned ten meters from the fence as the Lichtensstein’s hartebeest present at the time of the study may have concentrated in these areas.

At each sampling site a point quadrate survey of 225 random points (by means of a step-point method) was conducted to determine the botanical composition of the herbaceous layer. Tree rows of 75 points were located on each side of the enclosure fence and the nearest grass species to each point and the grass species height was recorded (see Figure 2.3 for schematic representation). If there was not an herbaceous species within the 25 cm of the point this was recorded as "bare ground". Cover of the herbaceous layer was determined using a quadrate method in which and 8-point scale with uneven class intervals was used, as described by Anderson and Walker (1974). Walker 1976) demonstrated that this scale was the most accurate and repeatable method for measuring herbaceous cover. The scale is as follows:
The above mentioned were chosen as they are the same methods used during the veld condition assessment surveys (Trollope et al, 1989) and so enabled comparison of results.

As well sampling inside and outside the enclosure, there waterholes in the Vlakteplaas east compartment were sampled at increasing distance from the water to determine the effect these waterholes have had on the composition and abundance of species in the herbaceous layer. The three waterholes included Hlamalala-south, Papanyane and Boyela-north as they all occurred in vleis. Roan prefers vlei (alluvial) grasslands (Heitkoning, 1993, Joubert, 1976), so only waterholes occurring in vleis were examined. This allowed of the effects of waterholes on the herbaceous layer in both the vleis and the grassland.

Eight transects were placed at each waterhole, two replicate transects in each of the four major directions leading away from the waterhole. As all three waterholes sampled occurred within vleis, four transects occurred within the vlei (two replicate transects in opposite directions from the waterhole), while the remaining four transects occurred in the grassland (two replicate transects in opposite directions from the waterhole) (see Figure 2.4 from schematic representation). Replicate transects were placed 20 meters apart. The minimum length of a transect was 150 metres, although transects were continued until the proportion of increaser II grass species dropped below 50%. This figure was used at it was thought that the natural proportion of increaser II grass species in this area was somewhere between 40 and 50% (Abates, pers.comm). The grass species were classified according Trollope (1990) with respect to their response to different grazing intensities (see Appendix 1).

In addition to the three waterholes sampled, two vlei grassland which did not contain waterholes were located and their composition, abundance, height and cover were determined for composition with the sampled vleis that did contain waterholes. This was to determine whether there were differences between vleis which contained waterholes with those that did not. The vlei system were Hlamala and Papanyane. The sampling methods were identical to those used to sample Nwashitsumbe enclosure, except that transects were extended beyond 150 metres until the proportion of increaser II grass species dropped below 50%. A point-step method was used where points were located every two metres on the transect. At each point the nearest grass species was identified and its height measured, while the herbaceous cover was measured using a 1X1 meter quadrant at every third point along the transect (i.e. every six metres).

Where more detail was needed to supplement the EAS vegetation assessment and veld condition assessment survey, a vegetation survey was conducted. This compared the grassland inside and outside the Nwashitsumbe enclosure which is 256 ha. In area and has been protected from large numbers of grazers since 1970, except for 20 roan in the 1970’s and 40 Lichtentein’s hartebeest since 1991. Specific attributes that were measured included composition, abundance, cover, and height of the herbaceous layer, using a point-step method. Composition of the herbaceous layer was determined according to the dry weight rank method described by Mannetje and Haydock (1963), while abundance, cover and height was determined using a quadrant method described by Walker (1976).

On each side of the enclosure three 150 m transects were run (i.e. 4 * 3 transects) along which the grass species was identified and its height measured every 2 meters and the basal cover was measured every 6 meters. Transects were replaced mid way down the enclosures fence line, and care was taken that they were not placed near the fence or drinking troughs as the animals have concentrated in these areas(The transects were placed next to the road, on the bottom side)

As well as sampling inside and outside the enclosure, three waterholes in the Vlakteplaas east compartment were sampled at increasing distance from the water to determine the effect these waterholes have had on the composition and abundance of species in the herbaceous layer. The three waterholes sampled included Hlamalala-south, Papayane and Boyela-north. As roan prefers vlei (alluvial) grasslands, only waterholes occurring in vlei's were examined. This allowed comparison of the effects of waterholes on the herbaceous layer between the vlei’s and the grassland. Eight transects were run at each waterhole, four into the vlei (two replicate transects on each side of the waterhole). Replicate transects were placed 20 meters apart. The minimum length of a transect was 150 meters, although transects were run until the proportion of increaser II grass species dropped to approximately 50%. There are 44 waterholes in this compartment, so the three waterholes were chosen so that a large proportion of the roan range was represented. This was to ensure that the observed vegetation changes have occurred at waterholes in all the areas in which roan occur. Two vlei grassland which did not contain waterholes were located and their composition, abundance, height and cover were determined for comparison with the sampled vleis that did contain waterholes. The vlei system sampled were Hlamalala and Papanyane. This work was conducted during December 1993 and January 1994.
